text: Stealing Part of a Production Language Model
metadata:
{'category_depth': 1, 'page_number': 2, 'parent_id': '50cea88092c648eb98f5c452d4549582', 'text_as_html': '

Stealing Part of a Production Language Model

', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/pdf', 'partitioner_type': 'vlm_partition', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf'}
text_as_html: Stealing Part of a Production Language Model

text: where w is multiplied elementwise by normalized x. Clearly this can be written as a diagonal matrix. Further, we can multiply this diagonal matrix by √h to cancel that factor in the denominator of Equation (4). Since n(x) = x/||x|| = x/√∑i x²i we get the result. Intuitively, the proof in Appendix C.2 relied on pre-multiplying the input projection weight of layers by a matrix S⁻¹, so that this cancelled the rotation S applied to the model's hidden state (called the 'residual stream' in mechanistic interpretability literature (Elhage et al., 2021)). Formally, if we let the input projection layer be M, we were using the fact that (MS⁻¹)(Sx) = Mx. However, since models with normalization layers use these before the linear input projection, the result of applying S to the hidden state, if we apply the same procedure, produces the activation (MS⁻¹)(Wn(Sx) + b) but since in general n and S do not commute, we cannot conclude that the S transformations preserve the transformer's outputs. We will show that if we take S = U an orthogonal matrix, then we still get a general impossibility result. To do this, we will need a simple result from linear algebra:
metadata:
{'category_depth': 1, 'page_number': 2, 'parent_id': '50cea88092c648eb98f5c452d4549582', 'text_as_html': '

where w is multiplied elementwise by normalized x. Clearly this can be written as a diagonal matrix. Further, we can multiply this diagonal matrix by √h to cancel that factor in the denominator of Equation (4). Since n(x) = x/||x|| = x/√∑i x²i we get the result.

Intuitively, the proof in Appendix C.2 relied on pre-multiplying the input projection weight of layers by a matrix S⁻¹, so that this cancelled the rotation S applied to the model\'s hidden state (called the \'residual stream\' in mechanistic interpretability literature (Elhage et al., 2021)). Formally, if we let the input projection layer be M, we were using the fact that (MS⁻¹)(Sx) = Mx. However, since models with normalization layers use these before the linear input projection, the result of applying S to the hidden state, if we apply the same procedure, produces the activation

(MS⁻¹)(Wn(Sx) + b)

but since in general n and S do not commute, we cannot conclude that the S transformations preserve the transformer\'s outputs. We will show that if we take S = U an orthogonal matrix, then we still get a general impossibility result.

To do this, we will need a simple result from linear algebra:

where w is multiplied elementwise by normalized x. Clearly this can be written as a diagonal matrix. Further, we can multiply this diagonal matrix by √h to cancel that factor in the denominator of Equation (4). Since n(x) = x/||x|| = x/√∑i x²i we get the result.

Intuitively, the proof in Appendix C.2 relied on pre-multiplying the input projection weight of layers by a matrix S⁻¹, so that this cancelled the rotation S applied to the model's hidden state (called the 'residual stream' in mechanistic interpretability literature (Elhage et al., 2021)). Formally, if we let the input projection layer be M, we were using the fact that (MS⁻¹)(Sx) = Mx. However, since models with normalization layers use these before the linear input projection, the result of applying S to the hidden state, if we apply the same procedure, produces the activation

(MS⁻¹)(Wn(Sx) + b)

but since in general n and S do not commute, we cannot conclude that the S transformations preserve the transformer's outputs. We will show that if we take S = U an orthogonal matrix, then we still get a general impossibility result.

text_as_html: Lemma C.2.

text: Let x ∈ Rʰ. Then the normalization map n(x) := x/||x|| commutes with orthogonal matrices U. Proof of Lemma C.2. We need to show that Ux/||x|| = Ux/||Ux||. This is true since x⊤U⊤Ux = x⊤x, so ||Ux|| = ||x||.

text_as_html:
Let x ∈ Rʰ. Then the normalization map n(x) := x/||x|| commutes with orthogonal matrices U.

Proof of Lemma C.2. We need to show that Ux/||x|| = Ux/||Ux||. This is true since x⊤U⊤Ux = x⊤x, so ||Ux|| = ||x||.

text: C.4. Proof of Lemma 4.2(ii) in Models With RMSNorm
metadata:
{'category_depth': 1, 'page_number': 2, 'parent_id': '50cea88092c648eb98f5c452d4549582', 'text_as_html': '

C.4. Proof of Lemma 4.2(ii) in Models With RMSNorm

', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/pdf', 'partitioner_type': 'vlm_partition', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf'}
text_as_html: C.4. Proof of Lemma 4.2(ii) in Models With RMSNorm

text: In Lemma C.2, we showed that orthogonal matrices U commute with normalization. Hence if we multiply all layer output weights by U, but pre-multiply all layer input projection weights by WU⊤W⁻¹, then the effect of the linear projection layer is (MWU⊤W⁻¹)(Wn(Ux) + b) = (MWU⊤W⁻¹)(WUn(x) + b) = M(Wn(x) + b) which is identical to the original model. Applying this procedure to all layers added to the hidden state (using the different W diagonal matrices each time) gives us a model gθ′(p) such that gθ′(p) = Ugθ′(p) so a different embedding projection matrix WU⊤ will give identical outputs to the original model gθ(p) (with embedding projection W). Note that we ignore what happens to b in the above arguments, since any sequence of affine maps applied to a constant b ∈ Rⁿ yields a constant b′ ∈ Rⁿ, and we can just use b′ instead of b in gθ′.
metadata:
{'category_depth': 1, 'page_number': 2, 'parent_id': '50cea88092c648eb98f5c452d4549582', 'text_as_html': '

(MWU⊤W⁻¹)(Wn(Ux) + b) = (MWU⊤W⁻¹)(WUn(x) + b) = M(Wn(x) + b)

which is identical to the original model. Applying this procedure to all layers added to the hidden state (using the different W diagonal matrices each time) gives us a model gθ′(p) such that gθ′(p) = Ugθ′(p) so a different embedding projection matrix WU⊤ will give identical outputs to the original model gθ(p) (with embedding projection W).

Note that we ignore what happens to b in the above arguments, since any sequence of affine maps applied to a constant b ∈ Rⁿ yields a constant b′ ∈ Rⁿ, and we can just use b′ instead of b in gθ′.

', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/pdf', 'partitioner_type': 'vlm_partition', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf'}
text_as_html:
In Lemma C.2, we showed that orthogonal matrices U commute with normalization. Hence if we multiply all layer output weights by U, but pre-multiply all layer input projection weights by WU⊤W⁻¹, then the effect of the linear projection layer is

(MWU⊤W⁻¹)(Wn(Ux) + b) = (MWU⊤W⁻¹)(WUn(x) + b) = M(Wn(x) + b)

which is identical to the original model. Applying this procedure to all layers added to the hidden state (using the different W diagonal matrices each time) gives us a model gθ′(p) such that gθ′(p) = Ugθ′(p) so a different embedding projection matrix WU⊤ will give identical outputs to the original model gθ(p) (with embedding projection W).

Note that we ignore what happens to b in the above arguments, since any sequence of affine maps applied to a constant b ∈ Rⁿ yields a constant b′ ∈ Rⁿ, and we can just use b′ instead of b in gθ′.

text: C.5. Proof of Lemma 4.2(ii) in Models With LayerNorm
metadata:
{'category_depth': 1, 'page_number': 2, 'parent_id': '50cea88092c648eb98f5c452d4549582', 'text_as_html': '

C.5. Proof of Lemma 4.2(ii) in Models With LayerNorm

', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/pdf', 'partitioner_type': 'vlm_partition', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf'}

element_id: 8ee683eac2ffe895a95bfb952af6eea6
text: The LayerNorm operation is the composition of a centering operation x ↦ x − x̄ with RMSNorm (i.e. first centering is applied, then RMSNorm). Therefore the identical argument to Appendix C.4 goes through, besides the fact that we need U to also commute with the centering operation. Since the centering operation fixes a (h − 1) dimensional subspace defined by 1⊤x = 0 where 1 ∈ Rʰ is the vector of ones, it is enough to impose an additional condition that U1 ∈ {−1, 1}.

text_as_html: The LayerNorm operation is the composition of a centering operation x ↦ x − x̄ with RMSNorm (i.e. first centering is applied, then RMSNorm). Therefore the identical argument to Appendix C.4 goes through, besides the fact that we need U to also commute with the centering operation. Since the centering operation fixes a (h − 1) dimensional subspace defined by 1⊤x = 0 where 1 ∈ Rʰ is the vector of ones, it is enough to impose an additional condition that U1 ∈ {−1, 1}.

text: C.6. Proof of Lemma 4.2(ii) in Models With Normalization ε ≠ 0
metadata:
{'category_depth': 1, 'page_number': 2, 'parent_id': '50cea88092c648eb98f5c452d4549582', 'text_as_html': '

C.6. Proof of Lemma 4.2(ii) in Models With Normalization ε ≠ 0

', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/pdf', 'partitioner_type': 'vlm_partition', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf'}
text_as_html: C.6. Proof of Lemma 4.2(ii) in Models With Normalization ε ≠ 0

text: We now extend to realistic models where the ε in the denominator of LayerNorm is not 0. We can do this because the only fact we used about x ↦ n(x) was that x ↦ n(Ux) was identical to x ↦ Un(x). In turn Lemma C.2 relied on ||Ux|| = ||x|| due to orthogonality. But adjusting n(x) to n′(x) := x/√1/h||x||² + ε (i.e. normalization with an epsilon), since ||x|| = ||Ux||, n′ commutes with U, and so the proofs in Appendix C.4 and Appendix C.5 still work when using n′ instead of n. Therefore finally, we have proven the impossibility result Lemma 4.2(ii) in all common model architectures (all non-residual networks that end with dense layers, and all transformers from Biderman (2024)).

We now extend to realistic models where the ε in the denominator of LayerNorm is not 0. We can do this because the only fact we used about x ↦ n(x) was that x ↦ n(Ux) was identical to x ↦ Un(x). In turn Lemma C.2 relied on ||Ux|| = ||x|| due to orthogonality. But adjusting n(x) to n′(x) := x/√1/h||x||² + ε (i.e. normalization with an epsilon), since ||x|| = ||Ux||, n′ commutes with U, and so the proofs in Appendix C.4 and Appendix C.5 still work when using n′ instead of n.

Therefore finally, we have proven the impossibility result Lemma 4.2(ii) in all common model architectures (all non-residual networks that end with dense layers, and all transformers from Biderman (2024)).

text: E. Efficient Recovery of Logits From Top k Logprobs APIs
metadata:
{'category_depth': 1, 'page_number': 3, 'parent_id': '39595787e77c444c9b96208b07a8287d', 'text_as_html': '

E. Efficient Recovery of Logits From Top k Logprobs APIs

', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/pdf', 'partitioner_type': 'vlm_partition', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf'}
text_as_html: E. Efficient Recovery of Logits From Top k Logprobs APIs

element_id: 7025dce3d242bb4e83e9bd293b3b4d89
text: In Section 5.3 of the main body, we presented a simple and practical method for extracting the entire logits vector via multiple queries to an API that only provides the top few logprobs and accepts a logit bias with each query. In this section we present more efficient methods. The method we presented earlier uses a reference token. We set this to some arbitrary value (e.g., 0) and then compare the logits for all other tokens to this one. This approach is numerically stable, but is slightly wasteful: of the top K logprobs returned by the API, one is always the reference token. Hence, we only recover K − 1 logits per query with this method. In this appendix, we present linear algebraic methods that are able to recover K logits per query to the top-K logprobs API.

{'category_depth': 1, 'page_number': 3, 'parent_id': '39595787e77c444c9b96208b07a8287d', 'text_as_html': '

This approach is numerically stable, but is slightly wasteful: of the top K logprobs returned by the API, one is always the reference token. Hence, we only recover K − 1 logits per query with this method.

In this appendix, we present linear algebraic methods that are able to recover K logits per query to the top-K logprobs API.

In Section 5.3 of the main body, we presented a simple and practical method for extracting the entire logits vector via multiple queries to an API that only provides the top few logprobs and accepts a logit bias with each query. In this section we present more efficient methods.

The method we presented earlier uses a reference token. We set this to some arbitrary value (e.g., 0) and then compare the logits for all other tokens to this one. This approach is numerically stable, but is slightly wasteful: of the top K logprobs returned by the API, one is always the reference token. Hence, we only recover K − 1 logits per query with this method.

In this appendix, we present linear algebraic methods that are able to recover K logits per query to the top-K logprobs API.

text: Setting: Recall that there is an unknown vector z = W · g θ (p) ∈ ℝ ℓ (i.e., the logits for a given prompt p) that we want to recover. We can make multiple queries to the API with the same prompt Q(p, b). Each query is specified by a vector b ∈ ℝ ℓ (a.k.a. the logit bias). We receive answers of the form (i, a i (z, b)) ∈ ℕ × ℝ, where i is a token index and a i (z, b) is a logprob:

text: Each query may receive multiple answers (namely, the K largest a i (z, b) values). For notational simplicity, we denote multiple answers to one query the same way as multiple queries each returning one answer. text: E.1. Warmup: Single Logprob API (K = 1)
metadata:
{'category_depth': 1, 'page_number': 3, 'parent_id': '39595787e77c444c9b96208b07a8287d', 'text_as_html': '

E.1. Warmup: Single Logprob API (K = 1)

', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/pdf', 'partitioner_type': 'vlm_partition', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf'}
text_as_html: E.1. Warmup: Single Logprob API (K = 1)

text: As a starting point, suppose the API only returns the single largest logprob (i.e., K = 1). The approach from Section 5.3 cannot work in this setting because we cannot obtain the logprob of both the reference token and another token at the same time, meaning we can recover less than 1 logit per query.
metadata:
{'category_depth': 1, 'page_number': 3, 'parent_id': '39595787e77c444c9b96208b07a8287d', 'text_as_html': '

As a starting point, suppose the API only returns the single largest logprob (i.e., K = 1). The approach from Section 5.3 cannot work in this setting because we cannot obtain the logprob of both the reference token and another token at the same time, meaning we can recover less than 1 logit per query.

', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/pdf', 'partitioner_type': 'vlm_partition', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf'}
text_as_html: As a starting point, suppose the API only returns the single largest logprob (i.e., K = 1). The approach from Section 5.3 cannot work in this setting because we cannot obtain the logprob of both the reference token and another token at the same time, meaning we can recover less than 1 logit per query.

text: The high-level idea to overcome this problem is that, instead of normalizing logits relative to a reference token, we shall normalize the logits to be logprobs. That is, we recover the logits with the normalization ∑ j exp(z j ) = 1. With this normalization it is no longer necessary to include a reference token in every query.

', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/pdf', 'partitioner_type': 'vlm_partition', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf'}

The high-level idea to overcome this problem is that, instead of normalizing logits relative to a reference token, we shall normalize the logits to be logprobs. That is, we recover the logits with the normalization ∑

j

exp(z

j

) = 1. With this normalization it is no longer necessary to include a reference token in every query.

text: Fix a token index i and let bi = B and bj = 0 for all j ≠ i. We query the API with this logit bias and assume that B is large enough that token i is returned: (i, ai(z, b)) ← O(p, b). From Equation 7,

Fix a token index i and let bi = B and bj = 0 for all j ≠ i. We query the API with this logit bias and assume that B is large enough that token i is returned:

(i, ai(z, b)) ← O(p, b).

From Equation 7,

', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/pdf', 'partitioner_type': 'vlm_partition', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf'}
text_as_html:
Fix a token index i and let bi = B and bj = 0 for all j ≠ i. We query the API with this logit bias and assume that B is large enough that token i is returned:

(i, ai(z, b)) ← O(p, b).

From Equation 7,

text: ai(z, b) = zi + bi - log (∑ℓj exp(zj + bj))
metadata: {'category_depth': 1, 'page_number': 4, 'parent_id': 'dac4baedb4a94d0e882f817440a4a797', 'text_as_html': '<math class="Formula" id="492a5c91e18948f7b9d4477c1511e859">ai(z, b) = zi + bi - log (∑ℓj exp(zj + bj))</math>', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/pdf', 'partitioner_type': 'vlm_partition', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf'}
text_as_html: <math class="Formula" id="492a5c91e18948f7b9d4477c1511e859">ai(z, b) = zi + bi - log (∑ℓj exp(zj + bj))</math>

element_id: fefa007a7bf8ab676a1c9f746e4192ce
text: = zi + B - log (exp(zi + B) + ∑j≠i exp(zj))
metadata: {'category_depth': 1, 'page_number': 4, 'parent_id': 'dac4baedb4a94d0e882f817440a4a797', 'text_as_html': '<math class="Formula" id="e362be98df214bc6b7f21b8067d9b51a">= zi + B - log (exp(zi + B) + ∑j≠i exp(zj))</math>', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/pdf', 'partitioner_type': 'vlm_partition', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf'}
text_as_html: <math class="Formula" id="e362be98df214bc6b7f21b8067d9b51a">= zi + B - log (exp(zi + B) + ∑j≠i exp(zj))</math>

element_id: 218e60c1b9c2b5e1a906f1bae00d78ea
text: = zi + B - log (exp(zi + B) - exp(zi) + ∑ℓj exp(zj)),
metadata: {'category_depth': 1, 'page_number': 4, 'parent_id': 'dac4baedb4a94d0e882f817440a4a797', 'text_as_html': '<math class="Formula" id="3e24c40810fd481cbedb0040b12eba1b">= zi + B - log (exp(zi + B) - exp(zi) + ∑ℓj exp(zj)),</math>', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/pdf', 'partitioner_type': 'vlm_partition', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf'}
text_as_html: <math class="Formula" id="3e24c40810fd481cbedb0040b12eba1b">= zi + B - log (exp(zi + B) - exp(zi) + ∑ℓj exp(zj)),</math>

element_id: bdda808e647abd2bbd0c7743352fac6e
text: ⟹ zi + B - ai(z, b) = log (exp(zi + B) - exp(zi) + ∑ℓj exp(zj)),
metadata: {'category_depth': 1, 'page_number': 4, 'parent_id': 'dac4baedb4a94d0e882f817440a4a797', 'text_as_html': '<math class="Formula" id="a041a0f6a566484f92ca107a7f332a5b">⟹ zi + B - ai(z, b) = log (exp(zi + B) - exp(zi) + ∑ℓj exp(zj)),</math>', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/pdf', 'partitioner_type': 'vlm_partition', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf'}
text_as_html: <math class="Formula" id="a041a0f6a566484f92ca107a7f332a5b">⟹ zi + B - ai(z, b) = log (exp(zi + B) - exp(zi) + ∑ℓj exp(zj)),</math>

element_id: ea7b66eeb9647bdeab6be1e68609a17d
text: ⟹ exp(zi + B - ai(z, b)) = exp(zi + B) - exp(zi) + ∑ℓj exp(zj),
metadata: {'category_depth': 1, 'page_number': 4, 'parent_id': 'dac4baedb4a94d0e882f817440a4a797', 'text_as_html': '<math class="Formula" id="8b40585ae6a64fff97bf243e32162772">⟹ exp(zi + B - ai(z, b)) = exp(zi + B) - exp(zi) + ∑ℓj exp(zj),</math>', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/pdf', 'partitioner_type': 'vlm_partition', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf'}
text_as_html: <math class="Formula" id="8b40585ae6a64fff97bf243e32162772">⟹ exp(zi + B - ai(z, b)) = exp(zi + B) - exp(zi) + ∑ℓj exp(zj),</math>

text: ⟹ exp(zi + B - ai(z, b)) - exp(zi + B) + exp(zi) = ∑ℓj exp(zj),
metadata: {'category_depth': 1, 'page_number': 4, 'parent_id': 'dac4baedb4a94d0e882f817440a4a797', 'text_as_html': '<math class="Formula" id="81fef6c280b74d63b0647d4161bf6a7c">⟹ exp(zi + B - ai(z, b)) - exp(zi + B) + exp(zi) = ∑ℓj exp(zj),</math>', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/pdf', 'partitioner_type': 'vlm_partition', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf'}
text_as_html: <math class="Formula" id="81fef6c280b74d63b0647d4161bf6a7c">⟹ exp(zi + B - ai(z, b)) - exp(zi + B) + exp(zi) = ∑ℓj exp(zj),</math>

text: ⟹ exp(zi) · (exp(B - ai(z, b)) - exp(B) + 1) = ∑ℓj exp(zj),
metadata: {'category_depth': 1, 'page_number': 4, 'parent_id': 'dac4baedb4a94d0e882f817440a4a797', 'text_as_html': '<math class="Formula" id="58e4c219b9e047b69812d229c122a3b4">⟹ exp(zi) · (exp(B - ai(z, b)) - exp(B) + 1) = ∑ℓj exp(zj),</math>', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/pdf', 'partitioner_type': 'vlm_partition', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf'}
text_as_html: <math class="Formula" id="58e4c219b9e047b69812d229c122a3b4">⟹ exp(zi) · (exp(B - ai(z, b)) - exp(B) + 1) = ∑ℓj exp(zj),</math>

element_id: e7a17c47e6b0ad53c5d9b8bc56cfda82
text: ⟹ exp(zi) = ∑ℓj exp(zj)/(exp(B - ai(z, b)) - exp(B) + 1),
metadata: {'category_depth': 1, 'page_number': 4, 'parent_id': 'dac4baedb4a94d0e882f817440a4a797', 'text_as_html': '<math class="Formula" id="f11ae3adf6294caca4460e4cd5dc1bfc">⟹ exp(zi) = ∑ℓj exp(zj)/(exp(B - ai(z, b)) - exp(B) + 1),</math>', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/pdf', 'partitioner_type': 'vlm_partition', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf'}
text_as_html: <math class="Formula" id="f11ae3adf6294caca4460e4cd5dc1bfc">⟹ exp(zi) = ∑ℓj exp(zj)/(exp(B - ai(z, b)) - exp(B) + 1),</math>

element_id: ceebb791bccf93d7872eea1700dfefae
text: ⟹ zi = log (∑ℓj exp(zj)) - log (exp(B - ai(z, b)) - exp(B) + 1).
metadata: {'category_depth': 1, 'page_number': 4, 'parent_id': 'dac4baedb4a94d0e882f817440a4a797', 'text_as_html': '<math class="Formula" id="d30df84362a44b29b2eb5eb8ad823144">⟹ zi = log (∑ℓj exp(zj)) - log (exp(B - ai(z, b)) - exp(B) + 1).</math>', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/pdf', 'partitioner_type': 'vlm_partition', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf'}
text_as_html: <math class="Formula" id="d30df84362a44b29b2eb5eb8ad823144">⟹ zi = log (∑ℓj exp(zj)) - log (exp(B - ai(z, b)) - exp(B) + 1).</math>

element_id: 5a9d68098ee8ab4a7bfe79abf39f598a
text: Thus if we normalize ∑ℓj exp(zj) = 1, we have

{'category_depth': 1, 'page_number': 4, 'parent_id': 'dac4baedb4a94d0e882f817440a4a797', 'text_as_html': '

Thus if we normalize ∑ℓj exp(zj) = 1, we have

', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/pdf', 'partitioner_type': 'vlm_partition', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf'}
text_as_html: Thus if we normalize ∑ℓj exp(zj) = 1, we have

(8)</math>', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/pdf', 'partitioner_type': 'vlm_partition', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf'}

text: E.2. Recovering K Logits From K Logprobs
metadata:
{'category_depth': 1, 'page_number': 4, 'parent_id': 'dac4baedb4a94d0e882f817440a4a797', 'text_as_html': '

E.2. Recovering K Logits From K Logprobs

', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/pdf', 'partitioner_type': 'vlm_partition', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf'}
text_as_html: E.2. Recovering K Logits From K Logprobs

text: The approach from the previous subsection extends to the setting where each API query returns the top K logprobs. In practice we work with K = 5. We are able to recover K logits. Again, instead of using a reference token to normalize the logits, we will normalize ∑j exp(zj) = 1. However, in this setting we will need to solve a K-by-K system of linear equations. Fix K token indices i1, · · · , iK and let bik = B for k ∈ {1, · · · , K} and bj = 0 for all j ∉ {i1, · · · , iK}. We query the API with this logit bias and assume that B is large enough that the logprobs for i1, · · · , iK are returned as the top K logprobs:

text: a_{i_k}(z, b) = z_{i_k} + B - \log \left( \sum_{i\in\{i_1,\cdots,i_K\}} \exp(z_i + B) + \sum_{i\notin\{i_1,\cdots,i_K\}} \exp(z_i) \right)
metadata: {'category_depth': 1, 'page_number': 5, 'parent_id': '4f36c83f65284132aaff714bfab6705e', 'text_as_html': '<math class="Formula" id="5e92dea1c0ab4bb3845d521ce374e696">a_{i_k}(z, b) = z_{i_k} + B - \\log \\left( \\sum_{i\\in\\{i_1,\\cdots,i_K\\}} \\exp(z_i + B) + \\sum_{i\\notin\\{i_1,\\cdots,i_K\\}} \\exp(z_i) \\right)</math>', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/pdf', 'partitioner_type': 'vlm_partition', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf'}
text_as_html: <math class="Formula" id="5e92dea1c0ab4bb3845d521ce374e696">a_{i_k}(z, b) = z_{i_k} + B - \log \left( \sum_{i\in\{i_1,\cdots,i_K\}} \exp(z_i + B) + \sum_{i\notin\{i_1,\cdots,i_K\}} \exp(z_i) \right)</math>

text: Stealing Part of a Production Language Model
metadata:
{'category_depth': 1, 'page_number': 1, 'parent_id': '76db6d1647274fd79b96bcc9d80c4b22', 'text_as_html': '

Stealing Part of a Production Language Model

', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/pdf', 'partitioner_type': 'vlm_partition', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf'}
text_as_html: Stealing Part of a Production Language Model

element_id: eaf9c7c93a6d9a1b0d21b13a557add1f
text:
where v ∈ ℝK is the vector with entries vk = exp(aik (z, b) − B). Hence ⎛ exp(zi₁) ⎞     ⎛ N ⎞
⎜ exp(zi₂) ⎟  = A⁻¹ · ⎜ N ⎟
⎜    ⋮     ⎟     ⎜ ⋮ ⎟
⎝ exp(ziK) ⎠     ⎝ N ⎠ = (diag(v) + (eᴮ − 1) vvᵀ/(1 − (eᴮ − 1)1ᵀv)) · 1 · N = (v + ((eᴮ − 1)vvᵀ1)/(1 − (eᴮ − 1)1ᵀv)) · N = (1 + ((eᴮ − 1)1ᵀv)/(1 − (eᴮ − 1)1ᵀv)) · N · v = N/(1 − (eᴮ − 1) ∑ⱼ vⱼ) · v, ⟹ zik = log (A⁻¹1N)k = log(Nvk/(1 − (eᴮ − 1)∑ⱼᴷ vⱼ)) = log(N exp(aik (z, b) − B)/(1 − (eᴮ − 1)∑ⱼᴷ exp(aiⱼ(z, b) − B))) = log N + aik (z, b) − B − log(1 − (eᴮ − 1)∑ⱼᴷ exp(aiⱼ(z, b) − B)) = log N + aik (z, b) − B − log(1 − (1 − e⁻ᴮ)∑ⱼᴷ exp(aiⱼ(z, b))). If we normalize N = 1, this gives us a formula for computing the logits: zik = aik (z, b) − B − log(1 − (1 − e⁻ᴮ)∑ⱼᴷ exp(aiⱼ(z, b))). (9) Note that setting K = 1 yields the same result as in Equation 8. Recovery using Equation 9 is more efficient than the method in Section 5.3, as we recover K logits zi₁, zi₂, · · · , ziK rather than just K − 1 logits. However, if B is large, numerical stability may be an issue. (And, if B is small, the logit bias may be insufficient to force the API to output the desired tokens by placing them in the top K.) Specifically, as B → ∞, we have (1 − e⁻ᴮ)∑ⱼᴷ exp(aiⱼ(z, b)) → 1 and so the logarithm in Equation 9 tends to log(1 − 1) = −∞; this means we may have catastrophic cancellation.

where v ∈ ℝK is the vector with entries vk = exp(aik (z, b) − B). Hence

⎛ exp(zi₁) ⎞ ⎛ N ⎞ ⎜ exp(zi₂) ⎟ = A⁻¹ · ⎜ N ⎟ ⎜ ⋮ ⎟ ⎜ ⋮ ⎟ ⎝ exp(ziK) ⎠ ⎝ N ⎠

= (diag(v) + (eᴮ − 1) vvᵀ/(1 − (eᴮ − 1)1ᵀv)) · 1 · N

= (v + ((eᴮ − 1)vvᵀ1)/(1 − (eᴮ − 1)1ᵀv)) · N

= (1 + ((eᴮ − 1)1ᵀv)/(1 − (eᴮ − 1)1ᵀv)) · N · v

= N/(1 − (eᴮ − 1) ∑ⱼ vⱼ) · v,

⟹ zik = log (A⁻¹1N)k

= log(Nvk/(1 − (eᴮ − 1)∑ⱼᴷ vⱼ))

= log(N exp(aik (z, b) − B)/(1 − (eᴮ − 1)∑ⱼᴷ exp(aiⱼ(z, b) − B)))

= log N + aik (z, b) − B − log(1 − (eᴮ − 1)∑ⱼᴷ exp(aiⱼ(z, b) − B))

= log N + aik (z, b) − B − log(1 − (1 − e⁻ᴮ)∑ⱼᴷ exp(aiⱼ(z, b))).

If we normalize N = 1, this gives us a formula for computing the logits:

zik = aik (z, b) − B − log(1 − (1 − e⁻ᴮ)∑ⱼᴷ exp(aiⱼ(z, b))).

(9)

Note that setting K = 1 yields the same result as in Equation 8.

Recovery using Equation 9 is more efficient than the method in Section 5.3, as we recover K logits zi₁, zi₂, · · · , ziK rather than just K − 1 logits. However, if B is large, numerical stability may be an issue. (And, if B is small, the logit bias may be insufficient to force the API to output the desired tokens by placing them in the top K.) Specifically, as B → ∞, we have (1 − e⁻ᴮ)∑ⱼᴷ exp(aiⱼ(z, b)) → 1 and so the logarithm in Equation 9 tends to log(1 − 1) = −∞; this means we may have catastrophic cancellation.

where v ∈ ℝK is the vector with entries vk = exp(aik (z, b) − B). Hence

⎛ exp(zi₁) ⎞ ⎛ N ⎞ ⎜ exp(zi₂) ⎟ = A⁻¹ · ⎜ N ⎟ ⎜ ⋮ ⎟ ⎜ ⋮ ⎟ ⎝ exp(ziK) ⎠ ⎝ N ⎠

= (diag(v) + (eᴮ − 1) vvᵀ/(1 − (eᴮ − 1)1ᵀv)) · 1 · N

= (v + ((eᴮ − 1)vvᵀ1)/(1 − (eᴮ − 1)1ᵀv)) · N

= (1 + ((eᴮ − 1)1ᵀv)/(1 − (eᴮ − 1)1ᵀv)) · N · v

= N/(1 − (eᴮ − 1) ∑ⱼ vⱼ) · v,

⟹ zik = log (A⁻¹1N)k

= log(Nvk/(1 − (eᴮ − 1)∑ⱼᴷ vⱼ))

= log(N exp(aik (z, b) − B)/(1 − (eᴮ − 1)∑ⱼᴷ exp(aiⱼ(z, b) − B)))

= log N + aik (z, b) − B − log(1 − (eᴮ − 1)∑ⱼᴷ exp(aiⱼ(z, b) − B))

= log N + aik (z, b) − B − log(1 − (1 − e⁻ᴮ)∑ⱼᴷ exp(aiⱼ(z, b))).

If we normalize N = 1, this gives us a formula for computing the logits:

zik = aik (z, b) − B − log(1 − (1 − e⁻ᴮ)∑ⱼᴷ exp(aiⱼ(z, b))).

(9)

Note that setting K = 1 yields the same result as in Equation 8.

Recovery using Equation 9 is more efficient than the method in Section 5.3, as we recover K logits zi₁, zi₂, · · · , ziK rather than just K − 1 logits. However, if B is large, numerical stability may be an issue. (And, if B is small, the logit bias may be insufficient to force the API to output the desired tokens by placing them in the top K.) Specifically, as B → ∞, we have (1 − e⁻ᴮ)∑ⱼᴷ exp(aiⱼ(z, b)) → 1 and so the logarithm in Equation 9 tends to log(1 − 1) = −∞; this means we may have catastrophic cancellation.

text_as_html: Related work.

text: Two works published during the responsible disclosure period use a similar procedure, and deal with numerical issues in different ways. (Chiu, 2024) start with a low B for the whole vocabulary, then increase B and ask for all tokens that haven't appeared before, and repeat until all tokens are covered. (Hayase et al., 2024) use the method in Appendix E.1, and set B = −ẑi, where ẑi is an estimate of zi inherent to their application. It is possible variants of this method have been discussed before our or these works, but we are not aware of further references.

metadata:

E.3. General Method

', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/pdf', 'partitioner_type': 'vlm_partition', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf'}
text_as_html: E.3. General Method

element_id: eef004f62db88e5c2cbb8b821cf2d1d8
text: In general, we may not have have full control over which logprobs the API returns or which logit bias is provided to the API. Thus we generalize the linear algebraic approach above to reconstruct the logits from arbitrary logit biases and tokens.

text: Here 𝟙[j = ik] is 1 if j = ik and 0 otherwise. If A is invertible, then this linear system can be solved to recover the logits z. Unfortunately, A is not invertible: Indeed, we know that the solution cannot be unique because shifting all the logits by the same amount yields the exact same answers ai(z, b) = ai(z + 1, b). That is, we expect a one-dimensional space of valid solutions to A · exp(z) = 0. To deal with this we simply add the constraint that z₁ = 0 or, equivalently, exp(z₁) = 1. This corresponds to the system

text: Here A₁:m,2:d denotes A with the first column removed. Note that we are setting m = ℓ - 1. This is the minimum number of query-answer pairs that we need. If we have more (i.e., m ≥ ℓ), then the system is overdetermined. Having the system be overdetermined is a good thing: the extra answers can help us recover the logprobs with greater accuracy. The least squares solution to the overdetermined system is given by

element_id: cd6cc26473c75d63fa3f0b7f2686ad2c
text: In the logprob-free API, we have produced attacks capable of recovering logits and ultimately the embedding hidden dimension and embedding matrix up to a similarity transform. We now provide lower bounds on the minimum number of queries required by any attacker attempting model stealing under the logprob-free API threat model.

element_id: 7eb9a8e1efc6e135f0c479c7979c23de
text: Lemma F.1.
metadata:
{'category_depth': 2, 'page_number': 3, 'parent_id': 'e58447e143924dde99101b0b3d4af5c9', 'text_as_html': '

Lemma F.1.

', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/pdf', 'partitioner_type': 'vlm_partition', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf'}
text_as_html: Lemma F.1.

element_id: 2dac648a1629a7d5401bff9d7746c9eb
text: Assume the entries of logit ∈ ℝl are i.i.d. uniform over [-B, 0]. To recover the vector logit up to ∞-norm error ε, the number of queries to O(p, ·) we need is at least: l log₂(B/ε)/log₂(l) Proof. The information content of a single logit value in [-B, 0] up to ∞-norm error ε is log₂(B/ε), assuming a uniform prior over ε-spaced points in the interval. Since the logits are independent, the information encoded in l logit values up to ∞-norm error ε is l log₂(100/ε). Any single query to O, no matter how well-crafted, yields at most log₂(l) bits, because the output is one of l distinct values. The minimum number of queries required is at least the total information content divided by the information per query, yielding the lower bound l log₂(B/ε)/ log₂(l). □ The restriction of biasing at most N tokens at a time gives us a lower bound of l log₂(B/ε)/log₂(N) queries, which is a factor of log₂(l)/ log₂(N) worse. For N = 300 and l ≈ 100,000, this is only a factor of 2. For B = 100 and N = 300, we thus need at least log₂(B/ε)/log₂(N) ≈ 0.81 + 0.12log₂(1/ε) queries per logit. If we want between 6 and 23 digits of precision, the lower bound corresponds to 1.53 to 3.57 queries per logit. We see that the best logprob-free attack in Table 3 is only about 1 query per logit worse than the lower bound. The main unrealistic assumption in Lemma F.1 is that the prior over the logit values is i.i.d. uniform over an interval. A better assumption might be that most of the logit values come from a light-tailed unimodal distribution. We leave more realistic lower bounds and attacks that make use of this better prior to future work.

The restriction of biasing at most N tokens at a time gives us a lower bound of

text_as_html:
Assume the entries of logit ∈ ℝl are i.i.d. uniform over [-B, 0]. To recover the vector logit up to ∞-norm error ε, the number of queries to O(p, ·) we need is at least:

l log₂(B/ε)/log₂(l)

Proof. The information content of a single logit value in [-B, 0] up to ∞-norm error ε is log₂(B/ε), assuming a uniform prior over ε-spaced points in the interval. Since the logits are independent, the information encoded in l logit values up to ∞-norm error ε is l log₂(100/ε).

Any single query to O, no matter how well-crafted, yields at most log₂(l) bits, because the output is one of l distinct values. The minimum number of queries required is at least the total information content divided by the information per query, yielding the lower bound l log₂(B/ε)/ log₂(l). □

The restriction of biasing at most N tokens at a time gives us a lower bound of

l log₂(B/ε)/log₂(N)

queries, which is a factor of log₂(l)/ log₂(N) worse. For N = 300 and l ≈ 100,000, this is only a factor of 2.

For B = 100 and N = 300, we thus need at least

log₂(B/ε)/log₂(N) ≈ 0.81 + 0.12log₂(1/ε)

queries per logit. If we want between 6 and 23 digits of precision, the lower bound corresponds to 1.53 to 3.57 queries per logit. We see that the best logprob-free attack in Table 3 is only about 1 query per logit worse than the lower bound.

The main unrealistic assumption in Lemma F.1 is that the prior over the logit values is i.i.d. uniform over an interval. A better assumption might be that most of the logit values come from a light-tailed unimodal distribution. We leave more realistic lower bounds and attacks that make use of this better prior to future work.

We do not carry out this attack in practice for models considered in this paper, and leave improving this algorithm as an open problem for future work. We make a few simplifying assumptions:

In this section, we outline an algorithm for extracting W up to an orthogonal h × h matrix, instead of merely up to a nonsingular h × h matrix as in Appendix C. We do not carry out this attack in practice for models considered in this paper, and leave improving this algorithm as an open problem for future work.

We make a few simplifying assumptions:

text: We merge the final LayerNorm weights γ into W by linearity.³ We assume the numerical precision is high enough that after the final LayerNorm, the hidden states are on a sphere. There is no degenerate lower-dimensional subspace containing all g₀(p) for all our queries p. We assume the ε in RMSNorm/LayerNorm is 0. This is not a critical assumption.

text: Again, we use the compact SVD on the query output matrix Q = U · Σ · V⊤. Here Q ∈ ℝl×n, U ∈ ℝl×h, Σ ∈ ℝh×h, and V⊤ ∈ ℝh×n. Note that the points g₀(p) lie on a sphere in ℝh, and U⊤ · W ∈ ℝh×h, hence U⊤ · W · g₀(p) lie on an ellipsoid in ℝh. From now on, it is convenient to work with the points xᵢ = U⊤ · W · g₀(pᵢ); note that we can compute these points directly, because we know both U and W · g₀(pᵢ). As ellipsoids are equivalently defined by x⊤Ax = 1 for some positive semidefinite (symmetric) matrix A ∈ ℝh×h, this implies the following statement:

element_id: e4895cd6dddd5911bf98e4bbf8ff6c6a
text: Lemma G.2. W = U · M−1 · O for some orthogonal matrix O.
metadata:
{'category_depth': 1, 'page_number': 4, 'parent_id': '603041c950ee4314ae854402deba5bf9', 'text_as_html': '

Lemma G.2. W = U · M−1 · O for some orthogonal matrix O.

', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/pdf', 'partitioner_type': 'vlm_partition', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf'}
text_as_html: Lemma G.2. W = U · M−1 · O for some orthogonal matrix O.

text: Proof. We know that gθ(pt) lie on a sphere. The equation x⊤t Axt = 1 is equivalent to x⊤t M⊤Mxt = 1, which is equivalent to ||Mxt|| = 1. This means that Mxt lie on a sphere. Because Mxt = M · U⊤ · W · gθ(pt), we have that M · U⊤ · W is a norm-preserving transformation on the points gθ(pt). By the assumption that gθ(pt) are not in a degenerate lower-dimensional subspace, we have that M · U⊤ · W =: O is a norm-preserving endomorphism of ℝh, hence an orthogonal matrix. This directly implies W = U · M−1 · O as claimed. □ This means that, to extract W up to an orthogonal matrix, it's enough to recover some M satisfying ||Mxt|| = 1 for all i. To compute M, we can actually recover the positive semi-definite A satisfying Lemma G.1, which would give us a feasible M by SVD or Cholesky decomposition. The final observation is that the system in Lemma G.1 (x⊤t Axt = 1 for all i) is linear in the h(h + 1)/2 distinct entries of A. By generating more than h(h + 1)/2 values for xt (and again assuming no degeneracy), we can therefore solve a large system of linear equations, and in principle recover A, and hence M, and hence W. Note that any solution A will be positive semidefinite because an overdetermined linear system has at most one solution. However, we do not know how to solve these systems of linear equations in h² variables efficiently (h > 750 in all our experiments); so in practice we resort to reconstructing weights up to an arbitrary h × h matrix, as described in Appendix C.

This directly implies W = U · M−1 · O as claimed. □

This means that, to extract W up to an orthogonal matrix, it\'s enough to recover some M satisfying ||Mxt|| = 1 for all i. To compute M, we can actually recover the positive semi-definite A satisfying Lemma G.1, which would give us a feasible M by SVD or Cholesky decomposition.

The final observation is that the system in Lemma G.1 (x⊤t Axt = 1 for all i) is linear in the h(h + 1)/2 distinct entries of A. By generating more than h(h + 1)/2 values for xt (and again assuming no degeneracy), we can therefore solve a large system of linear equations, and in principle recover A, and hence M, and hence W. Note that any solution A will be positive semidefinite because an overdetermined linear system has at most one solution. However, we do not know how to solve these systems of linear equations in h² variables efficiently (h > 750 in all our experiments); so in practice we resort to reconstructing weights up to an arbitrary h × h matrix, as described in Appendix C.

', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/pdf', 'partitioner_type': 'vlm_partition', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf'}
text_as_html:
Proof. We know that gθ(pt) lie on a sphere. The equation x⊤t Axt = 1 is equivalent to x⊤t M⊤Mxt = 1, which is equivalent to ||Mxt|| = 1. This means that Mxt lie on a sphere. Because Mxt = M · U⊤ · W · gθ(pt), we have that M · U⊤ · W is a norm-preserving transformation on the points gθ(pt). By the assumption that gθ(pt) are not in a degenerate lower-dimensional subspace, we have that M · U⊤ · W =: O is a norm-preserving endomorphism of ℝh, hence an orthogonal matrix. This directly implies W = U · M−1 · O as claimed. □

This means that, to extract W up to an orthogonal matrix, it's enough to recover some M satisfying ||Mxt|| = 1 for all i. To compute M, we can actually recover the positive semi-definite A satisfying Lemma G.1, which would give us a feasible M by SVD or Cholesky decomposition.

The final observation is that the system in Lemma G.1 (x⊤t Axt = 1 for all i) is linear in the h(h + 1)/2 distinct entries of A. By generating more than h(h + 1)/2 values for xt (and again assuming no degeneracy), we can therefore solve a large system of linear equations, and in principle recover A, and hence M, and hence W. Note that any solution A will be positive semidefinite because an overdetermined linear system has at most one solution. However, we do not know how to solve these systems of linear equations in h² variables efficiently (h > 750 in all our experiments); so in practice we resort to reconstructing weights up to an arbitrary h × h matrix, as described in Appendix C.

text: H.1. Quantization
metadata:
{'category_depth': 1, 'page_number': 4, 'parent_id': '603041c950ee4314ae854402deba5bf9', 'text_as_html': '

H.1. Quantization

', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/pdf', 'partitioner_type': 'vlm_partition', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf'}
text_as_html: H.1. Quantization

element_id: 5aef53a6295df87adb8b4db12e6b3f75
text: Quantization is a popular strategy for decreasing a model's memory footprint and speeding up inference. In addition to these benefits, using lower-precision number representations also effectively adds noise. As noted in Section 8.2, adding noise to the output logits could prevent our attack. A natural question that follows is, does quantization add sufficient noise to make our attack ineffective or more difficult to carry out? For a simple test, we quantize Llama-7B at both 8-bits and 4-bits, and compare our baseline attack (Section 4.1) to the default 16-bit implementation. We quantize using bitsandbytes (Dettmers et al., 2022), which HuggingFace supports for out-of-the-box quantization of model weights and lower-precision inference (Figure 6). We observe no meaningful differences at different levels of quantization, querying each model results in recovering the same same embedding matrix dimension h in the same number of queries. Given that 8-bit and 4-bit quantization are generally observed to not have a large impact on performance, this is perhaps an unsurprising result; any noise from quantization does not seem to have a meaningful impact on the logits (in the context of our attack).

text_as_html:
Quantization is a popular strategy for decreasing a model's memory footprint and speeding up inference. In addition to these benefits, using lower-precision number representations also effectively adds noise. As noted in Section 8.2, adding noise to the output logits could prevent our attack. A natural question that follows is, does quantization add sufficient noise to make our attack ineffective or more difficult to carry out?

For a simple test, we quantize Llama-7B at both 8-bits and 4-bits, and compare our baseline attack (Section 4.1) to the default 16-bit implementation. We quantize using bitsandbytes (Dettmers et al., 2022), which HuggingFace supports for out-of-the-box quantization of model weights and lower-precision inference (Figure 6). We observe no meaningful differences at different levels of quantization, querying each model results in recovering the same same embedding matrix dimension h in the same number of queries. Given that 8-bit and 4-bit quantization are generally observed to not have a large impact on performance, this is perhaps an unsurprising result; any noise from quantization does not seem to have a meaningful impact on the logits (in the context of our attack).

text: H.2. Noise
metadata:
{'category_depth': 1, 'page_number': 4, 'parent_id': '603041c950ee4314ae854402deba5bf9', 'text_as_html': '

H.2. Noise

', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/pdf', 'partitioner_type': 'vlm_partition', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf'}
text_as_html: H.2. Noise

text: One natural defense to our attacks is to obfuscate the logits by adding noise. This will naturally induce a tradeoff between utility and vulnerability—more noise will result in less useful outputs, but increase extraction difficulty. We empirically measure this tradeoff in Figure 5(c). We consider noise added directly to the logits, that is consistent between different queries of the same prompt. To simulate this, we directly add noise to our recovered logits, and recompute the extracted embedding matrix. For GPT-2, we measure the RMSE between the true embedding matrix and the embedding matrix extracted with a specific noise level; for ada and babbage, we measure the RMSE between the noisy extracted weights and the weights we extracted in the absence of noise. We normalize all embedding matrices (to have ℓ2 norm 1) before measuring RMSE.

In (c), the RMSE between extracted embeddings as a function of the standard deviation of Gaussian noise added to the logits.

text: Figure 7. On the left, we plot the singular values that are extracted using our attack on GPT-2 small—the estimated hidden dimension is near 768. On the right, we post-hoc extend the dimensionality of the weight matrix to 1024, as described in Section 8. This misleads the adversary into thinking the model is wider than it actually is.

text_as_html: 1. Product Description:

text: The Bonded Manifolds family of products contains products that are alternative for Manifold-Monoblocks. They are 2,3 and 4 gang UV bonded manifold, LB and closed stopcocks. This Risk management plan covers all risk management activities required for bonded manifolds development projects as well as their design change projects. Their lifecycle stages of such projects are divided to:

This Risk management plan covers all risk management activities required for bonded manifolds development projects as well as their design change projects.

Their lifecycle stages of such projects are divided to:

text_as_html: 3. Definitions:

text: FMEA: Failure Mode and Effect Analysis. Harm: physical injury or damage to the health of people, or damage to property or the environment. Hazard: potential source of harm. Hazardous situation: circumstances in which people, property, or the environment are exposed to one or more hazard(s). Risk: combination of the probability of occurrence of harm and the severity of that harm. RPN: Risk Priority number ALARP: As Low As Reasonably Possible. AFAP: As Far as Possible.
metadata:
{'category_depth': 1, 'page_number': 1, 'parent_id': 'aa92520938a2487697bc47c12f575637', 'text_as_html': '

FMEA: Failure Mode and Effect Analysis.

Harm: physical injury or damage to the health of people, or damage to property or the environment.

Hazard: potential source of harm.

Hazardous situation: circumstances in which people, property, or the environment are exposed to one or more hazard(s).

Risk: combination of the probability of occurrence of harm and the severity of that harm.

RPN: Risk Priority number

ALARP: As Low As Reasonably Possible.

AFAP: As Far as Possible.

', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/pdf', 'partitioner_type': 'vlm_partition', 'filename': 'RMP - Bonded Manifolds - Rev B_scanned for TF.pdf'}

FMEA: Failure Mode and Effect Analysis.

Harm: physical injury or damage to the health of people, or damage to property or the environment.

Hazard: potential source of harm.

Hazardous situation: circumstances in which people, property, or the environment are exposed to one or more hazard(s).

Risk: combination of the probability of occurrence of harm and the severity of that harm.

RPN: Risk Priority number

ALARP: As Low As Reasonably Possible.

AFAP: As Far as Possible.

text: 4.1. Risk Management Process description:
metadata:
{'category_depth': 1, 'page_number': 2, 'parent_id': '33f65b5a0bcd4efe8f824c89eb244b18', 'text_as_html': '
4.1. Risk Management Process description:
', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/pdf', 'partitioner_type': 'vlm_partition', 'filename': 'RMP - Bonded Manifolds - Rev B_scanned for TF.pdf'}
filename: RMP - Bonded Manifolds - Rev B_scanned for TF.pdf
text_as_html: 4.1. Risk Management Process description:

text: Risk Management process will be performed as required by ISO 14971:2007 and BS EN ISO 14971:2012, ("Medical Devices – Application of risk management to medical devices") and in accordance with Elcam's SOP# 03-01-21. The process will include Risk Analysis, Risk Evaluation and Risk Control and at the end of the process also Production & Post Production information. (The method for risk analysis and evaluation to be used is mainly FMEA (Fail Mode & Effect Analysis). Other techniques will be used as well when needed. The emphasis will be on risks primarily to the patient, but also to the operator, other persons, other equipment and the environment occurs during the product shelf life and/or in-use life. Risks which effect Elcam's image or Elcam's manufacturing facilities that do not affect product's safety or performance are not included within this Risk Management Process.
metadata:
{'category_depth': 1, 'page_number': 2, 'parent_id': '33f65b5a0bcd4efe8f824c89eb244b18', 'text_as_html': '

(The method for risk analysis and evaluation to be used is mainly FMEA (Fail Mode & Effect Analysis). Other techniques will be used as well when needed.

The emphasis will be on risks primarily to the patient, but also to the operator, other persons, other equipment and the environment occurs during the product shelf life and/or in-use life. Risks which effect Elcam\'s image or Elcam\'s manufacturing facilities that do not affect product\'s safety or performance are not included within this Risk Management Process.

Risk Management process will be performed as required by ISO 14971:2007 and BS EN ISO 14971:2012, ("Medical Devices – Application of risk management to medical devices") and in accordance with Elcam's SOP# 03-01-21.

The process will include Risk Analysis, Risk Evaluation and Risk Control and at the end of the process also Production & Post Production information.

(The method for risk analysis and evaluation to be used is mainly FMEA (Fail Mode & Effect Analysis). Other techniques will be used as well when needed.

The emphasis will be on risks primarily to the patient, but also to the operator, other persons, other equipment and the environment occurs during the product shelf life and/or in-use life. Risks which effect Elcam's image or Elcam's manufacturing facilities that do not affect product's safety or performance are not included within this Risk Management Process.

text: 4.1.1. Risk Analysis:
metadata:

text_as_html: 4.1.1. Risk Analysis:

text: First step is listing the intended use or purpose of the product and its characteristics related to its safety. Then, identifying the known or foreseeable hazards and hazardous situations in normal and fault conditions, their causes and estimating the risks for each hazardous situation. This identification will initially be performed by a review meeting after design Input phase, after establishing the Device Requirements and the Product Specifications.

element_id: 78aebbc033bde764f0dda905576c379f
text: The identified hazardous situations are evaluated for their risk probability of occurrence (P), severity (S) and detectability (D) according to the scales described below. Afterwards the RPN number is calculated by multiplying the ratings for each hazard and the acceptability is determined according to the acceptance criteria. Each parameter (P, S, or D) will be analyzed in order to rank and estimate the risk:

metadata:
{'category_depth': 2, 'page_number': 1, 'parent_id': 'c4edf0adc4224131be5a34c0ce05ee07', 'text_as_html': '

Degree of Severity (S):

filename: RMP - Bonded Manifolds - Rev B_scanned for TF.pdf
text_as_html: Degree of Severity (S):

element_id: 79aa1de45d96de2e85df4d38583df1f8
text: S Rating Severity Severity to Patient/User Severity to Elcam Severity to Manufacture 1 Minor All is fine up to small discomfort, minor damage in performance. All is fine up to deviations in spec border. Small effect on equipment or product, a few production hours loss. 2 Medium Degradation in performance without harm. Damage to image, do not meet spec. Degradation in equipment or its operation small effect on product in non-functional characters, a few days loss. 4 Severe The part does not function but does not cause harm. Need to replace parts, severe impact to image, will not meet fundamental characteristic in spec. Medium degradation in equipment or its operation affecting product in non-functional characters, two-three weeks loss. 6 Severe - critical The product does not function and causes injury or condition requiring medical treatment. Severe impact to image, product will not meet the requirements of spec, market loss. High deterioration in equipment or its operation severely affecting production or product functionality, several week losses. 8 Critical Severe harm to patient: death, irreversible injury or condition or long term medical aid. Low suit, market loss. Severe damage to equipment, not being able to produce at all or producing non-functional products, loss of more than month and a half.

text_as_html: Degree of Detectability (D):

text: D Rating Defect Detection 1 Defect, if occurred, will always be detected at Elcam during production. 2 Defect, if occurred, will occasionally be detected at Elcam during production. 3 Defects, if occurred, will rarely be detected at Elcam or Will be detected by customer (not end user). 4 Defects, if occurred, will not be detected at Elcam. It will always be detected by the end user.

RPN calculation:

filename: RMP - Bonded Manifolds - Rev B_scanned for TF.pdf
text_as_html: RPN calculation:

text: The calculation of the Risk Priority Number (RPN) is done by multiplying the risk analysis values: (S x P) or (S x P x D). According to the calculated RPN value the priority for mitigation is determined (Risk Priority Level).
metadata:
{'category_depth': 1, 'page_number': 2, 'parent_id': '49f8df127b5940f7b9baa8e8d9451f6c', 'text_as_html': '

The calculation of the Risk Priority Number (RPN) is done by multiplying the risk analysis values: (S x P) or (S x P x D).

According to the calculated RPN value the priority for mitigation is determined (Risk Priority Level).

', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/pdf', 'partitioner_type': 'vlm_partition', 'filename': 'RMP - Bonded Manifolds - Rev B_scanned for TF.pdf'}
filename: RMP - Bonded Manifolds - Rev B_scanned for TF.pdf
text_as_html:
The calculation of the Risk Priority Number (RPN) is done by multiplying the risk analysis values: (S x P) or (S x P x D).

According to the calculated RPN value the priority for mitigation is determined (Risk Priority Level).

element_id: fe91079ebdf7f1d894ee22e8fea312e4
text: Green area – Low rated risks. Yellow area – Medium rated risks. *Risks in the ALARP/AFAP area (ALARP is according to definition of ISO 14971:2007 AFAP is according to definition in BS EN ISO 14971:2012). Acceptable but require additional controls and monitoring. There should be actions to reduce them further and they require periodical review. Red area – High rated risk, additional actions should be taken to reduce this risk.

{'category_depth': 1, 'page_number': 2, 'parent_id': '49f8df127b5940f7b9baa8e8d9451f6c', 'text_as_html': '

Red area – High rated risk, additional actions should be taken to reduce this risk.

text: 4.1.3. Risk Control:
metadata:
{'category_depth': 1, 'page_number': 1, 'parent_id': '17bd8097779245cbbd15b5ca9a4bda89', 'text_as_html': '

4.1.3. Risk Control:

', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/pdf', 'partitioner_type': 'vlm_partition', 'filename': 'RMP - Bonded Manifolds - Rev B_scanned for TF.pdf'}
filename: RMP - Bonded Manifolds - Rev B_scanned for TF.pdf
text_as_html: 4.1.3. Risk Control:

element_id: 7b03faa7c1a3bc07ac0cb3f5d7053615
text: For each risk, whether marked in green, yellow or red, Risk Control measures should be taken in order to reduce the severity of the harm or reduce the probability of its occurrence. The risk control measures should be one or more of the following options in the priority order listed:
metadata:
{'category_depth': 1, 'page_number': 1, 'parent_id': '17bd8097779245cbbd15b5ca9a4bda89', 'text_as_html': '

For each risk, whether marked in green, yellow or red, Risk Control measures should be taken in order to reduce the severity of the harm or reduce the probability of its occurrence.

The risk control measures should be one or more of the following options in the priority order listed:

', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/pdf', 'partitioner_type': 'vlm_partition', 'filename': 'RMP - Bonded Manifolds - Rev B_scanned for TF.pdf'}
filename: RMP - Bonded Manifolds - Rev B_scanned for TF.pdf
text_as_html:
For each risk, whether marked in green, yellow or red, Risk Control measures should be taken in order to reduce the severity of the harm or reduce the probability of its occurrence.

The risk control measures should be one or more of the following options in the priority order listed:

element_id: affb8b5400f50195abe65217ef39b7ac
text: a. Inherent safety by design b. Protective measures in the product itself or in the manufacturing process. c. Information for safety
metadata:
{'category_depth': 1, 'page_number': 1, 'parent_id': '17bd8097779245cbbd15b5ca9a4bda89', 'text_as_html': '
  • a. Inherent safety by design
  • b. Protective measures in the product itself or in the manufacturing process.
  • c. Information for safety
', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/pdf', 'partitioner_type': 'vlm_partition', 'filename': 'RMP - Bonded Manifolds - Rev B_scanned for TF.pdf'}
filename: RMP - Bonded Manifolds - Rev B_scanned for TF.pdf
text_as_html:
• a. Inherent safety by design
  • b. Protective measures in the product itself or in the manufacturing process.
  • c. Information for safety

element_id: e479cb89cd8006536cbafd0524de3d5d
text: Risk Control includes defining the measures to be taken in order to reduce the risks, Implementation of the risk control measures and verification of their implementation and their effectiveness, Residual Risk Evaluation after the Implementation. If measures are not practical Risk to Benefit Analysis should be made in order to demonstrate whether the products' benefits outweigh the residual risk. Risks arising from the risk control measures should be identified as well. At the end of the risk control measures, the Acceptability of the Overall Residual Risk is to be documented.
metadata:
{'category_depth': 1, 'page_number': 1, 'parent_id': '17bd8097779245cbbd15b5ca9a4bda89', 'text_as_html': '

Risk Control includes defining the measures to be taken in order to reduce the risks, Implementation of the risk control measures and verification of their implementation and their effectiveness, Residual Risk Evaluation after the Implementation. If measures are not practical Risk to Benefit Analysis should be made in order to demonstrate whether the products\' benefits outweigh the residual risk. Risks arising from the risk control measures should be identified as well.

At the end of the risk control measures, the Acceptability of the Overall Residual Risk is to be documented.

', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/pdf', 'partitioner_type': 'vlm_partition', 'filename': 'RMP - Bonded Manifolds - Rev B_scanned for TF.pdf'}
filename: RMP - Bonded Manifolds - Rev B_scanned for TF.pdf
text_as_html:
Risk Control includes defining the measures to be taken in order to reduce the risks, Implementation of the risk control measures and verification of their implementation and their effectiveness, Residual Risk Evaluation after the Implementation. If measures are not practical Risk to Benefit Analysis should be made in order to demonstrate whether the products' benefits outweigh the residual risk. Risks arising from the risk control measures should be identified as well.

At the end of the risk control measures, the Acceptability of the Overall Residual Risk is to be documented.

text_as_html: 4.1.4. Production & Post-production Information:

element_id: 9a056ea9d574a2ab6ae1f4412b375ae2
text: After the end of the development phase, for each family of products, the risks should be reviewed according to information gained from the production of the device and afterwards information after the device is being sent to customers (customers' feedback and satisfaction, complaints, information from users, operators etc.). This information shall be evaluated to identify any unrecognized hazards and hazardous situations and to evaluate acceptability of risks that were identified previously.

text_as_html: 5. Documenting Risk Management Process

element_id: 716f8ca07cd5696422bfddfe0acfa439
text: The Risk Management Process will be documented in the product's Design History File (DHF). It will be according to the format specified in Appendix 5 of SOP#3-01-21. The risk management file will be managed as a controlled document, revised with the progression of the risk management process and all its revisions will be kept for process tracking in the design history file. Risk general management documents related to production and post production stages will be documented separately afterwards in "Risk Management" folder at the EPDM system.

The Risk Management Process will be documented in the product's Design History File (DHF). It will be according to the format specified in Appendix 5 of SOP#3-01-21. The risk management file will be managed as a controlled document, revised with the progression of the risk management process and all its revisions will be kept for process tracking in the design history file.

Risk general management documents related to production and post production stages will be documented separately afterwards in "Risk Management" folder at the EPDM system.

element_id: ace02ed1e06ee458676d2a5f8f1fba45
text: This document outlines the risk management activities for Bonded Manifold family of products. It determines the scales of rating them and the acceptance criteria. It also determines the means of reviewing and verifying them and the responsibilities. The product lifecycle stages in which this plan is applicable are as described in the scope.

text: Purpose:
metadata: {'category_depth': 0, 'emphasized_text_contents': ['Purpose:'], 'emphasized_text_tags': ['b'], 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': '2021d894eaaee156a8dd330deeb6b6c0'}

text: The purpose of this document is planning the risk management process for the Bonded Manifold family of products.
metadata: {'category_depth': 0, 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': '2021d894eaaee156a8dd330deeb6b6c0'}

text: Definitions:
metadata: {'category_depth': 0, 'emphasized_text_contents': ['Definitions:'], 'emphasized_text_tags': ['b'], 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': '2021d894eaaee156a8dd330deeb6b6c0'}

element_id: 3b2426aedd625330170d5ad2fe2cf17c
text: FMEA: Failure Mode and Effect Analysis.
metadata: {'category_depth': 0, 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': '2021d894eaaee156a8dd330deeb6b6c0'}

element_id: 9150daedd4fde2ed22be90fe2b5077d9
text: Harm: physical injury or damage to the health of people, or damage to property or the environment.
metadata: {'category_depth': 0, 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': '2021d894eaaee156a8dd330deeb6b6c0'}

text: Hazard: potential source of harm.
metadata: {'category_depth': 0, 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': '2021d894eaaee156a8dd330deeb6b6c0'}

text: Hazardous situation: circumstances in which people, property, or the environment are exposed to one or more hazard(s).
metadata: {'category_depth': 0, 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': '2021d894eaaee156a8dd330deeb6b6c0'}

text: Risk: combination of the probability of occurrence of harm and the severity of that harm.
metadata: {'category_depth': 0, 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': '2021d894eaaee156a8dd330deeb6b6c0'}

element_id: 4d5ad846dd9c514cbb3926b8606e6edc
text: RPN: Risk Priority number, Multiply of Severity*Probability*Detectability.
metadata: {'category_depth': 0, 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': '2021d894eaaee156a8dd330deeb6b6c0'}

element_id: 86dedc78eeac52f2a6c8c0f07d344320
text: ALARP:  As Low As Reasonably Possible.
metadata: {'category_depth': 0, 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': '2021d894eaaee156a8dd330deeb6b6c0'}

text: AFAP:  As Far as Possible.
metadata: {'category_depth': 0, 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['eng', 'por'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': '2021d894eaaee156a8dd330deeb6b6c0'}

text: Method:
metadata: {'category_depth': 0, 'emphasized_text_contents': ['Method:'], 'emphasized_text_tags': ['b'], 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': '2021d894eaaee156a8dd330deeb6b6c0'}

element_id: 95dbdaeee62dc545d5bf018bfcde5551
text: 4.1. Risk Management Process description:
metadata: {'category_depth': 0, 'emphasized_text_contents': ['4.1.', 'Risk Management Process description:'], 'emphasized_text_tags': ['b', 'b'], 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['fra', 'eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': '2021d894eaaee156a8dd330deeb6b6c0'}

element_id: a2763acd7a3f549c56ab41e0c6db70d6
text: Risk Management process will be performed as required by ISO 14971:2007 and BS EN ISO 14971:2012, ("Medical Devices – Application of risk management to medical devices") and in accordance with Elcam's SOP# 03-01-21.
metadata: {'category_depth': 0, 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': '2021d894eaaee156a8dd330deeb6b6c0'}

text: The process will include Risk Analysis, Risk Evaluation and Risk Control and at the end of the process also Production & Post Production information.
metadata: {'category_depth': 0, 'emphasized_text_contents': ['Risk Analysis', 'Risk Evaluation', 'Risk Control', 'Production & Post Production information.'], 'emphasized_text_tags': ['b', 'b', 'b', 'b'], 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': '2021d894eaaee156a8dd330deeb6b6c0'}

text: (The method for risk analysis and evaluation to be used is mainly FMEA (Fail Mode & Effect Analysis). Other techniques will be used as well when needed.
metadata: {'category_depth': 0, 'emphasized_text_contents': ['FMEA'], 'emphasized_text_tags': ['b'], 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': '2021d894eaaee156a8dd330deeb6b6c0'}

text: The emphasis will be on risks primarily to the patient, but also to the operator, other persons, other equipment and the environment occurs during the product shelf life and/or in-use life. Risks which effect Elcam's image or Elcam's manufacturing facilities that do not affect product's safety or performance are not included within this Risk Management Process.
metadata: {'category_depth': 0, 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': '2021d894eaaee156a8dd330deeb6b6c0'}

element_id: a429833ce5251cdb500d13fb91fa53dd
text: 4.1.1. Risk Analysis:
metadata: {'category_depth': 0, 'emphasized_text_contents': ['4.1.1.', 'Risk Analysis', 'Risk Analysis', ':'], 'emphasized_text_tags': ['b', 'b', 'i', 'i'], 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': '2021d894eaaee156a8dd330deeb6b6c0'}

text: First step is listing the intended use or purpose of the product and its characteristics related to its safety.
metadata: {'category_depth': 0, 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': '2021d894eaaee156a8dd330deeb6b6c0'}

element_id: 6f6f4ac2ad478c929537c969de4bdd18
text: Then, identifying the known or foreseeable hazards and hazardous situations in normal and fault conditions, their causes and estimating the risks for each hazardous situation. This identification will initially be performed by a review meeting after design Input phase, after establishing the Device Requirements and the Product Specifications.
metadata: {'category_depth': 0, 'emphasized_text_contents': [', identifying the known or foreseeable hazards and hazardous situations', 'causes', 'risks'], 'emphasized_text_tags': ['b', 'b', 'b'], 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': '2021d894eaaee156a8dd330deeb6b6c0'}

text: 4.1.2. Risk Evaluation:
metadata: {'category_depth': 0, 'emphasized_text_contents': ['4.1.2.', 'Risk Evaluation:', 'Risk Evaluation:'], 'emphasized_text_tags': ['b', 'b', 'i'], 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': '2021d894eaaee156a8dd330deeb6b6c0'}

text: The identified hazardous situations are evaluated for their risk probability of occurrence (P), severity (S) and detectability (D) according to the scales described below. Afterwards the RPN number is calculated by multiplying the ratings for each hazard and the acceptability is determined according to the acceptance criteria.
metadata: {'category_depth': 0, 'emphasized_text_contents': ['probability', '(P)', 'severity (S)', 'detectability (D)', 'RPN', 'acceptance criteria'], 'emphasized_text_tags': ['b', 'b', 'b', 'b', 'b', 'b'], 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': '2021d894eaaee156a8dd330deeb6b6c0'}

element_id: eebaf6a76c4813083195ea75ee21ddd6
text: Each parameter (P, S, or D) will be analyzed in order to rank and estimate the risk:
metadata: {'category_depth': 0, 'emphasized_text_contents': ['P', 'S', 'D'], 'emphasized_text_tags': ['b', 'b', 'b'], 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': '2021d894eaaee156a8dd330deeb6b6c0'}

element_id: d95a080d465ce38bf5f970a7d19c49db
text: Probability of occurrence (P):
metadata: {'category_depth': 0, 'emphasized_text_contents': ['Probability of occurrence', 'Probability of occurrence', '(', 'P', 'P'], 'emphasized_text_tags': ['b', 'i', 'i', 'b', 'i'], 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': '2021d894eaaee156a8dd330deeb6b6c0'}

text: Value Probability for occurrence Verbal description for probability 1 Less than 1 in 1,000,000 Evidence that will not occur 2 1:10,000 - 1:1,000,000 Low probability, rare occurrence 4 1:1,000 - 1:10,000 Will occur several times 6 1:100 - 1:1,000 Will occur several times, often 8 More than 1:100 High probability, likely to occur frequently
metadata:
{'emphasized_text_contents': ['Value', 'Probability for occurrence', 'Verbal description for probability'], 'emphasized_text_tags': ['b', 'b', 'b'], 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'text_as_html': '

41:1,000 - 1:10,000Will occur several times
61:100 - 1:1,000Will occur several times, often

', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': '2021d894eaaee156a8dd330deeb6b6c0'}

element_id: 67b15db61ba0b27dbea144a4fae19741
text: Degree of Severity (S):
metadata: {'category_depth': 0, 'emphasized_text_contents': ['Degree of Severity', 'Degree of Severity', '(', 'S', 'S'], 'emphasized_text_tags': ['b', 'i', 'i', 'b', 'i'], 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': '2021d894eaaee156a8dd330deeb6b6c0'}

element_id: ab2354b0c7cea2a5d954da106df6d3e6
text: S Rating Severity Severity to Patient/User Severity to Elcam Severity to Manufacture 1 Minor All is fine up to small discomfort, minor damage in performance. All is fine up to deviations in spec border. Small effect on equipment or product, a few production hours loss. 2 Medium Degradation in performance without harm. Damage to image, do not meet spec. Degradation in equipment or its operation small effect on product in non-functional characters, a few days loss. 4 Severe The part does not function but does not cause harm. Need to replace parts, severe impact to image, will not meet fundamental characteristic in spec. Medium degradation in equipment or its operation affecting product in non-functional characters, two-three weeks loss. 6 Severe - critical The product does not function and causes injury or condition requiring medical treatment. Severe impact to image, product will not meet the requirements of spec, market loss. High deterioration in equipment or its operation severely affecting production or product functionality, several week losses. 8 Critical Severe harm to patient: death, irreversible injury or condition or long term medical aid. Low suit, market loss. Severe damage to equipment, not being able to produce at all or producing non-functional products, loss of more than month and a half.

text: Rate according to severity to patient/user or their environment. If the risk has an effect on several fields (patient/user and/or Elcam and/or Manufacture) rate according to the worst of all.

element_id: 0a587efda8e8325e3318ea853ff08f9a
text: Degree of Detectability (D) – Relevant mainly to Process risks:
metadata: {'category_depth': 0, 'emphasized_text_contents': ['Degree of Detectability (D) – Relevant mainly to Process risks:', 'Degree of Detectability (D) – Relevant mainly to Process risks:'], 'emphasized_text_tags': ['b', 'i'], 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': '2021d894eaaee156a8dd330deeb6b6c0'}

text: D Rating Defect Detection 1 Defect, if occurred, will always be detected at Elcam during production. 2 Defect, if occurred, will occasionally be detected at Elcam during production. 3 Defects, if occurred, will rarely be detected at Elcam or Will be detected by customer (not end user). 4 Defects, if occurred, will not be detected at Elcam. It will always be detected by the end user.
metadata:

2Defect, if occurred, will occasionally be detected at Elcam during production.
3Defects, if occurred, will rarely be detected at Elcam or Will be detected by customer (not end user).
4Defects, if occurred, will not be detected at Elcam. It will always be detected by the end user.

element_id: fa36c144a3952ba69d3aab6a306f544b
text: RPN calculation:
metadata: {'category_depth': 2, 'emphasized_text_contents': ['RPN calculation:'], 'emphasized_text_tags': ['i'], 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': '2021d894eaaee156a8dd330deeb6b6c0'}

text: The calculation of the Risk Priority Number (RPN) is done by multiplying the risk values:         (S x P) or (S x P x D).
metadata: {'category_depth': 0, 'emphasized_text_contents': [':', '(S x P)', '(S x P x D)'], 'emphasized_text_tags': ['b', 'b', 'b'], 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': 'fa36c144a3952ba69d3aab6a306f544b'}

text: According to the calculated RPN value the priority for mitigation is determined (Risk Priority Level).
metadata: {'category_depth': 0, 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': 'fa36c144a3952ba69d3aab6a306f544b'}

element_id: 9b51beb894d2e41cc36f6d29e3bd37ba
text: Risk Priority Levels:
metadata: {'category_depth': 0, 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': 'fa36c144a3952ba69d3aab6a306f544b'}

element_id: 8e36b70a594b079d3ce6b85f41f5fcab
text: (S*P) value Color Risk priority Level (S*P)≤8 (Green) Low 8<(S*P) ≤32 (Yellow) Medium (ALARP/AFAP*) 32< (S*P) (Red) High
